head.title: Gristede's Sign Fails The Zoning Test

hedline.hl1: Gristede's Sign Fails The Zoning Test

abstract.p: Arlene Simon letter says Gristede's canopy on Upper West Side is not legal in accordance with New York City zoning (S)

block.p: As president of Landmark West, a community organization working to preserve the architectural heritage of the Upper West Side of Manhattan, I read the article ''What Went Up Must Go Down, Critics of Sign Say'' (Feb. 8) with great interest.

As president of Landmark West, a community organization working to preserve the architectural heritage of the Upper West Side of Manhattan, I read the article ''What Went Up Must Go Down, Critics of Sign Say'' (Feb. 8) with great interest.

I strongly disagree with the Buildings Department's statement that the Gristede's canopy is a legal sign. The department is charged with enforcing the City Zoning Resolution which, among other things, regulates signage. In the C6-4A zoning district where this 86th Street Gristede's is located, Zoning Resolution Section 32-652 prohibits signs from projecting more than 18 inches over the sidewalk, and Section 32-653 prohibits canopy signage from covering more than 12 square feet, having letters more than 12 inches, being illuminated or saying anything more than the name and address.
Even if the Gristede's canopy has the required Transportation Department permit, its signage clearly violates the Zoning Resolution.
